div.head: SCENE I.
div.stage: Enter Startup, wrapped in a blanket, followed by Close.

sp.speaker: Startup
sp.l: Where are we now? 'tis verie cold, why do'st not
Lead me to some house?

sp.speaker: Close
sp.l: What, at this time a night?
All people are a bed, the verie Owles
Are in their dead sleep; or if we could
Be admitted, would you venture a this fashion,
And publish your disgrace, proclaime your selfe
Coward, and lay some imputation
Upon the place you came from, where your hopes
May yet be faire for marriage? This brunt over.
To meet some Drunkard now were comfortable,
Whose eyes enflamed might serve for torches,
Or he might spit flapdragons†flapdragonA raisin or other thing thus caught and eaten. Obsolete (OED n. 1C). from his fire
Of Sack, and light us: But no sober man,
Considering what case you are in, sir,
By my consent should see you.

sp.speaker: Startup
sp.l: Ha, what's that?

sp.speaker: Close
sp.l: Where, where? a fire-drake†fire-drakeA comet or a large meteor, esp. viewed as an omen or portent. Obsolete (OED n. 2A)..

sp.speaker: Startup
sp.l: Now 'tis gone: 'tis bright
Agen, Is't not a spirit? Oh deliver me.

sp.speaker: Close
sp.l: I have heard some such things use to walke the fields.

sp.speaker: Startup
sp.l: What shall I do?

sp.speaker: Close
sp.l: Pray, pray with as much strength
As if you had no land, or were confined
To my annuity: Now I feare no spirits;
This riches makes us cowards; Hide your selfe,
I will go neerer.

sp.speaker: Startup
sp.l: Dost know the devill if thou seest him, Close?
A pox of love, if this be the reward on't;
Some call it fire, but I finde no such matter;
I am frozen to the Blanket, and my teeth
Strike one another, and keep time like hammers
That beat a Psalme upon the vertuous Anvile;
I do beleeve if they were beaten out,
They would make false Dyce, there's quicksilver in 'em,
I know already by their dancing.

sp.speaker: Close
sp.l: Sir, where are you?

sp.speaker: Startup
sp.l: Here I am still.

sp.speaker: Close
sp.l: Y'are a dead man.

sp.speaker: Startup
sp.l: More terrour? what's the matter?

sp.speaker: Close
sp.l: 'Tis my Master with a darke.
Lanthorne, that pursues us: By
This darknesse, 'tis his voice, wrap your selfe up,
And roule into some ditch, flight will betray us.

sp.speaker: Startup
sp.l: I had as good be kill'd, but yet I'll venture.

sp.speaker: Close
sp.l: 'Tis he indeed, and more than I expected:
The matters do not fadge well with his Mistresse.

div.stage: Enter Hartwell with a lantern.In the 1833 edition of The Constant Maid, the editor added in the stage directions that Hartwell is carrying a lantern when he enters the scene. This clarification does not appear in the original text.

sp.speaker: Hartwell
sp.l: What a sweet thing is night? how calme and harmlesse?
No whispering, but of leaves, on which the breath
Of heaven playes Music to the birds that slumber;
Here are no objects to betray our sence
To repentance, nor can women, thus
Advantag'd by the Tapers of the night,
Spread their temptations to undoe poore man:
What a fine book is heaves? which we may read
Best now, when every Star is a faire letter:
How much they wrong thee night, which call thee guilty
Of rapes and murders: 'Tis the day, that like
A glorious whore, engages men to act 'em,
And taking then the darknesse to obscure 'em:
We unjustly lay the shame upon thy browes,
That art so innocent; Thou never sawest them
Befriended with this silence; I begin
To wander: There's no wildernesse abroad,
To him that's lost at home.

sp.speaker: Close
sp.l: Sir.

sp.speaker: Hartwell
sp.l: Who's that?

sp.speaker: Close
sp.l: One that has taken paines for you to night:
I am Close.

sp.speaker: Hartwell
sp.l: What mak'st thou here?

sp.speaker: Close
sp.l: I wait upon
My charge; I led your Rivall a procession
In's shirt, perswading him you had resolv'd
To cut his throat else; he's hard by at's prayers,
And thinkes you ha' pursued him.

sp.speaker: Hartwell
sp.l: Ha, I'll do't;
Show me the foole, by all my hopes I'll kill him,
And send his base heart as a present to her:

Fate has preserved me with this revenge,The 1833 edition reads: “Fate has preserved me [, sure, for] this revenge.” The editor included this to clarify that Hartwell is claiming fate has destined him to exact revenge on his rival.
And I will not delay his death a minute.

sp.speaker: Close
sp.l: You wo'not kill him basely?

sp.speaker: Hartwell
sp.l: No.

sp.speaker: Close
sp.l: Why not?
There is no feare but he'll live long enough;
I'll undertake he never shall go provided
To fight w'ee; and for other satisfaction,
Name it, and take it; so I'll fetch him to ye.

sp.speaker: Hartwell
sp.l: Stay, I have been too passionate, let him live
To be her punishment; that's revenge enough,
While I pursue my owne wayes.

sp.speaker: Close
sp.l: Whither now?

sp.speaker: Hartwell
sp.l: Whither thou must not follow, by thy honesty,
I charge thee come not after me.

sp.speaker: Close
sp.l: That bindes my attendance, sir.

sp.speaker: Hartwell
sp.l: But not when I command
The contrary, if thou dost move this way,
Thou drawest my anger; Minde the preservation
Of the tame thing you undertooke; Farewell,
If thou dost love me, follow not, nor question
'Tis in my power to loose thee or my selfe.

sp.speaker: Close
sp.l: I cannot see i'th'darke with spectacles,
And mine owne eyes ha' lost him o'the suddaine;
Well, I must hope the best; What shall I do
With my hen-hearted lover, that would give
Halfe his estate his colde fit were well over:
I shall make worke for the Physicians :
Candles and Cullices will never restore him;
If he but scape with life, I am not sorry,
He may be a souldier, and indure the trenches;
I put him first to the becomming sufferance:
But what are these? an army of hornes and Halberds?
Upon my conscience, the Watch; I thought
The fields had not been haunted with these goblins:
I cannot run; If I should squat, and they finde me,
There were no mercy but Bride-well,In the 1833 edition, the editor chose to clarify Shirley’s meaning by adding: “there were no mercy [for me] but Bridewell.”
Or some such lovely place; I am resolv'd
To cast away a few good words upon 'em,
A leg and worshipping; the Constable
That leads the rusty Regiment will quit me,
I passe the gates wo't often, and so may
The devill if he pay the Porter; blesse you:
My masters what a clocke is't?

sp.speaker: Watchman 1
sp.l: Who's theere?

sp.speaker: Constable
sp.l: I charge you stand.

sp.speaker: Close
sp.l: Your worship may do much.

sp.speaker: Constable
sp.l: Where have you beene?

sp.speaker: Close
sp.l: At Islington, and please you, about businesse.

sp.speaker: Constable
sp.l: Some thiefe, I warrant him, no honest man,
I know by his basket hilt, some rogue that watches,
The fields are pester'd with such sturdy robbers.

sp.speaker: Close
sp.l: He is a rogue that watches, for my part.

sp.speaker: Constable
sp.l: He cals my watchmen rogues.

sp.speaker: Watchman 1
sp.l: How Mr. Constable? you are one your selfe.

sp.speaker: Constable
sp.l: A way with him.

sp.speaker: Close
sp.l: Good sir.

sp.speaker: Watchman 2
sp.l: We will provide you a lodging.

sp.speaker: Close
sp.l: Where?

sp.speaker: Constable
sp.l: New Prison.

sp.speaker: Close
sp.l: But are you in earnest, Gentlemen?
If there be no remedy.

sp.speaker: Watchman 2
sp.l: We'll humble you.

sp.speaker: Close
sp.l: I have a companion hereabouts: where are you Sir?

sp.speaker: Startup
sp.l: Here in the ditch.

sp.speaker: Constable
sp.l: They seldome go alone:
We'll finde him out; ha sirra.

sp.speaker: Startup
sp.l: I thanke you honest men: where art thou Close?

sp.speaker: Close
sp.l: Here; these good men will helpe us to a lodging.

sp.speaker: Startup
sp.l: Blessing on their hearts, I am almost starv'd.

sp.speaker: Constable
sp.l: Yes, we'll do you that favour; Come away, sir.

sp.speaker: Startup
sp.l: Whether shall we go now?

sp.speaker: Close
sp.l: To prison.

sp.speaker: Startup
sp.l: How, Close?

sp.speaker: Watchman 1
sp.l: You shal be close enough.

sp.speaker: Startup
sp.l: D'ee heare, sweet Gentlemen?

sp.speaker: Close
sp.l: I follow, Sir, I cannot leave you in adversity;
All this is for your health, cleane straw is warme, sir;
You have the benefit of being naked:
I shall have worke to morrow in the woollen.

sp.speaker: Constable
sp.l: Away, away; bring them away

div.head: SCENE II.
div.stage: A Room in mistresse Bellamy's Home.

sp.speaker: Bellamy
sp.l: I heard some noise; looke, call up the servants,
See if the Gentleman be a bed; I'm troubled.

sp.speaker: Nurse
sp.l: Oh Mistrisse?

sp.speaker: Bellamy
sp.l: What's the matter?

sp.speaker: Nurse
sp.l: Mr. Startup is not a bed, and here is all is left
Of Mr. Hartwell.

sp.speaker: Bellamy
sp.l: This is verie strange.

sp.speaker: Nurse
sp.l: I dare not tell her of his shiftThe 1833 annotation for this line clarifies that “I dare not tell her of his shift” means that the Nurse dares not to tell her about Hartwell having put on Startup’s clothes., they're gone,
The doores I found left open, and no signe
Which way they are bestowed.

sp.speaker: Bellamy
sp.l: This puzzles me:
Pray Heaven there be no mischiefe in this absence:
Is Franck abed?

sp.speaker: Nurse
sp.l: Yes.

sp.speaker: Bellamy
sp.l: What should move'em
To leave my house so late, and Mr. Hartwell
Without his clothes? Some knock there:
Beshrew me but I trembled.

sp.speaker: Nurse
sp.l: 'Tis a stranger,
And sayes he would speake with you.

sp.speaker: Bellamy
sp.l: At this late houre?
What accidents are these? from whence?

sp.speaker: Nurse
sp.l: I know not.

sp.speaker: Bellamy
sp.l: Has he no name? what should this meane?

sp.speaker: Nurse
sp.l: He sayes he is a Countrey-man of Mr. Startups.

sp.speaker: Bellamy
sp.l: Admit him, he perhaps does bring some newes.

div.stage: Enter Countrey-man.In the 1833 edition, the editor also added stage directions for the Nurse to go back and forth from the door.

sp.speaker: Countrey-man
sp.l: By your leave Mistresse, pardon my importunitieimportunitieThe quality or fact of being persistent or pressing in making requests, demands, or offers, esp. so as to cause irritation or distress; importune behaviour or character (OED n. “importunity” 1A).
At so unfit an houre.

sp.speaker: Bellamy
sp.l: Y'are welcome, sir.

sp.speaker: Country-man
sp.l: I met with fortunate directions,
Though I came late; I understand you have
A guest, one Startup of Northampton-shire,
That comes a wooing to your daughter.

sp.speaker: Bellamy
sp.l: Such an one there was that supt with us, and went
To bed; but since, as I have faith, I know not
Which way he has convey'd himselfe; another
Gentleman too is missing, and his Rivall.

sp.speaker: Countrey-man
sp.l: Pray do not mock me, Lady, I ha rid

div.l: A great way, and the businesse much concernes him.

sp.speaker: Bellamy
sp.l: You may beleeve me, he is no such treasure
I should conceale him.

sp.speaker: Countrey-man
sp.l: Then I see you dally:
Know, Mistresse, you may slack your preparations,
Your daughter must look out another husband,
He is contracted.

sp.speaker: Bellamy
sp.l: How?

sp.speaker: Countrey-man
sp.l: And something more,
Gotten with child one, that without blushing
I cannot call my daughter; he shall make
Her credit straight agen, although my fortunes
Have no equalitie with his, I shall
Find Law to force him.

sp.speaker: Frances
sp.l: You preferr'd this sutor,
This newes returnes my bloud.

sp.speaker: Bellamy
sp.l: Sir, you shall find
All truth I have deliver'd, I am not sorrie,
To heare this newes, this is no time to seek him:
Please you accept the lodging that was his,
My servant shall attend you in the morning,
To help your search.

sp.speaker: Countrey-man
sp.l: You seeme a noble Gentlewoman,
I take your courtesie.

sp.speaker: Bellamy
sp.l: Nurse, a light; pray walk, sir.

sp.speaker: Frances
sp.l: I was unkind to Hartwell, he not wise;
But love still apprehends too much, or nothing.

sp.speaker: Bellamy
sp.l: Frances, a word: do not you know what is
Become o' these Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Frances
sp.l: Not I, their absence
Is strange to me.

sp.speaker: Bellamy
sp.l: Oh, Franck, I am undone.

sp.speaker: Frances
sp.l: Good Heaven, forbid.

sp.speaker: Bellamy
sp.l: This Gentleman, Mr. Hartwell,
Whom we shall never see agen, I feare.

sp.speaker: Frances
sp.l: How, mother? are you acquainted
With any cause to feare thus.

sp.speaker: Bellamy
sp.l: 'Tis in vaine
To tell thee how I loved him.

sp.speaker: Frances
sp.l: Blesse my senses! you love him?

sp.speaker: Bellamy
sp.l: 'Bove all the world, affectionately plac'd him
Too neere my heart.

sp.speaker: Frances
sp.l: I heard you made pretence
Of Love, to trie him for my sake; and pardon me,
If yet I dare not beleeve more.

sp.speaker: Bellamy
sp.l: Oh Franck—

sp.speaker: Frances
sp.l: My heart doth thrill, I feele a coldnesse run
Through all my veines already.

sp.speaker: Bellamy
sp.l: I had no other thought,
At first; but wisely to distinguish whether
His heart was fixt on thee, or my estate;
With resolution, if I found him more
A Courtier of thy fortune than thy person,
To punish him with losse of both: But Love
Hath chang'd both scene and title in our Comedy,
And what I meant should shipwrack all his hopes,
Hath ruin'd us, his modest and calme answer:
To accept my tender, with such force and reason
Directed to my fancie, turn'd my purpose,
And made me his indeed, his perfect Lover:
But now we ha' both lost him.

sp.speaker: Frances
sp.l: All the pietie
That ever taught children to love their mother,
Will but suffice to keep my heart obedient.
Was ever Maid so miserable? Was there
No other, in my fate, to rivall me
I live too long; oh breake, breake my poore heart;
For she that gave me life, hath took it from me.

sp.speaker: Bellamy
sp.l: Why do you weep?

sp.speaker: Frances
sp.l: I do not weep, or if
I do, I know not why.

sp.speaker: Bellamy
sp.l: Now I perceive
Thy duty was but counterfeit, you love him,
Upon my life you love him still; Have my
Commands no more respect? My care and love
So ill rewarded, that my heart desiring
One comfort in the world, and shall my childe
Rise up to take it from me?

sp.speaker: Frances
sp.l: Alas I knew not
You loved him too, indeed I had rather die
Than you should call me rebell.

sp.speaker: Bellamy
sp.l: Now I see
The cause of his departure in this fashion,
Pray heaven he have not made away himselfe:
Did ever childe deceive a mother so?
And rise without my blessing, yet
You may stay, wherefore should I despaire
Of his returne? You say you could not tell
That I affected him.

sp.speaker: Frances
sp.l: Indeed not I,
And do believe it now against my will;
But I am your daughter.

sp.speaker: Bellamy
sp.l: Show it, in confirming
Your selfe to my desires, and what is past,
I can forgive you, if he come againe:
Will you be rul'd, and show no favour to him?
For 'tis in you, I see, to make me happy;
I will not tie you to affect the other,
Choose any for your husband but this man,
My love and prayers shall go along with you;
Answer.

sp.speaker: Frances
sp.l: Indeed I dare not, yet could I

Put off the knowledge that you are a mother—The editor of the 1833 text included “Put off the knowledge that you are [my] mother.” It is important to note how this changes the meaning of this piece of dialogue. Frances telling Bellamy to disregard the fact that she is generally a mother as opposed to her own mother is a significant distinction. She is emphasizing that Bellamy should have been more empathetic towards her for this reason, and not have withheld the truth from her.

sp.speaker: Bellamy
sp.l: What then?

sp.speaker: Frances
sp.l: Though in imagination I allow you
The greatest woman in the earth, whose frowne
Could kill, and eyes at pleasure make alive
Agen; I could say—

sp.speaker: Bellamy
sp.l: Pray let's heare.

sp.speaker: Frances
sp.l: I durstdurstIntransitive (Inflected dare, durst (also dares, dared.) To have boldness or courage (to do something); to be so bold as (OED v.1 1A). tell you,
In confidence of my cause, that you betray
Two innocents to sorrow; and though heaven
Looke on, and seem to smile upon your cruelty,
Yet there is punishment for divorcing those
Whose hearts that hath conjoyned: I durst tell you,
Though all your terrours were prepared to punish
My bold defence; you were a tyrant.

sp.speaker: Bellamy
sp.l: How?

sp.speaker: Frances
sp.l: A most unjust, a sacrilegious tyrant.

sp.speaker: Bellamy
sp.l: You would not be so violent.

sp.speaker: Frances
sp.l: That thus,
Not only ruine and deface the Altar,
But steal away the very Sacrifice,
And I durst adde and smile upon your anger.
Though as you frown'd death stood in every wrinckle,
My soul's above your tyranny, and would
From torturing flame, receive new fire of love,
And make your eye faint to behold the brightnesse
Of my poore bodies Martyrdome; and if ever
Love shewed a miracle, my heart should beare
The Characters of him you have torne from it,
With beames about it like a Saint that suffer'd:
But as you are my mother, thus I kneele
And beg a pardon for my innocence,
If that offend you; Live you happy still,
And be the Mistris of your vowes, live to
Enjoy whom you affect, may every houre
Returne new blessings on you both; renew
Your spring, and let him thinke you young againe,
And let me beg but this for all my duty;
Against that day you marry him to provide
My Coffin, for I feare I shall, not have
Breath many minutes after, to pray for you.
The herbs that shall adorne your Bridall chamber,
Will serve my Funerall, and deck my Merse;
Beneath which you should say, there lies your daughter
That dies to shew obedience.

sp.speaker: Bellamy
sp.l: Why shouldst thou
Continue thus to him?

sp.speaker: Frances
sp.l: I know he loves me, yet hereafter your affections
May not.

sp.speaker: Bellamy
sp.l: But never procure thee one sad thought;

Now I have tried you both; assure my childe,The text here is rather unintelligible which has led a few editors of this play to assume that this passage was potentially jumbled together at the press and some of the dialogue was lost in the process. In most versions of the play, editors have left this passage as is and disregarded their lost meaning. However, the 1833 version attempts to separate this passage where the editor believed certain words are lost.
I loved him but for thee, dispose thy selfe
To be his Bride: This newes, at his returne,
Will make all well to rest.

sp.speaker: Frances
sp.l: Can this be true?

sp.speaker: Bellamy
sp.l: 'Twere sin to mocke thee any more: To bed.

sp.speaker: Frances
sp.l: I'll spend all night
In prayers for you, mother: Oh my Hartwell

div.head: SCENE III.
div.stage: A Room in Justice Clement's House.

sp.speaker: Playfaire
sp.l: I am bound ever to thee.

sp.speaker: Cousen
sp.l: Does she not become her rich cloathes too?

sp.speaker: Playfaire
sp.l: The morning never look'd
So fresh, nor Venus with more charmes upon her:
Adon would melt before her eye, and wooe her
Her kisses, at expence of his last breath:
Cupid himselfe, could he but see, would fall
In love with her, and throwing away his shafts,
Offer the empty quiver to her eyes,
Ambitious to fill it with her beames;
The least of which, would wound more hearts, than all
His stocke of golden Arrowes.

sp.speaker: Cousen
sp.l: No more Raptures.

sp.speaker: Playfaire
sp.l: Didst thou not know before, that love is able,
Without the helpe of Sacke, to make a Poet,
My nimble Mercury, Joves Herald in
Reversion?

sp.speaker: Cousen
sp.l: I must confesse
I had a trick of Mercury when I pick'd
His pocket for the Keyes.

sp.speaker: Playfaire
sp.l: He never mist 'em?

sp.speaker: Cousen
sp.l: His eyes were drench'd in fuds, and I return'd em
Ere they recover'd light.

sp.speaker: Playfaire
sp.l: 'Twas excellent;
He walkes in darknesse still.

sp.speaker: Cousen
sp.l: D'ee think he'll know her?

sp.speaker: Playfaire
sp.l: His cloathes already have
Made him forget himselfe, or if he have
But the remembrance of such a woman;
The more he sees her now, the more he'l thinke
The change impossible.

sp.speaker: Cousen
sp.l: Where ha' you left him?

sp.speaker: Playfaire
sp.l: I'th' Gallery, where with much patience,The 1833 edition reads, “I’the gallery, where with much [im]patience.” This changes the meaning significantly. It could be that Shirley is being sarcastic here and the 1833 editor chose to emphasize this, but this addition is up to the reader’s interpretation.
He does expect his highnesse will send for him.

sp.speaker: Cousen
sp.l: Then all runs smoothe, his wonder still continues.

sp.speaker: Playfaire
sp.l: I fed that humour artificially;
He is halfe perswaded all's but a dream,
To which imagination his clothes
Are a great help, because he paid not for 'em:
Sometimes he is very merry, then agen
He struts about with such a scurvy pride,
As some new crept into Nobility;
When men of their first Livery come to see 'em;
His honour has so chang'him, that he now
Knowes not of what Religion he is;
Or if he chance to thinke of his first faith,
He spits o'th hangings, and excused with,
I do not like the Story, 'tis apocryphallapocryphallOf doubtful authenticity; spurious, fictitious, false; fabulous, mythical. (OED adj. “apocryphal” 1A).:
Sometimes he'll offer at a jest, and talke
Non-sense with him that has been seaven yeares Lorded;
Frowne upon any man that will presume
To have more knowledge, in worse clothes; I told him
It was his Graces pleasure he should be
Controuler of the Masque, and he did sweat,
As he were studying for some mighty oathes
To cleere the presence: he is here; away.

sp.speaker: Hornet
sp.l: And you are Master of the house, Sir Clement,
For so I heard you call'd.

sp.speaker: Sir Clement
sp.l: It is my name,
Sir Giles, unworthy of this grace his Highnesse
Is daign'd to shew in honouring of my daughter.

sp.speaker: Hornet
sp.l: And was she married this morning, say you?

sp.speaker: Sir Clement
sp.l: This morne she lost her Virgin name.

sp.speaker: Hornet
sp.l: I have not seen her yet, nor any of the Ladies,
You have but little noise methinkes in the house.

sp.speaker: Sir Clement
sp.l: It would offend his Grace.

sp.speaker: Hornet
sp.l: Who, as you say, came hither privately, with a small traine
Of Lords; Would I might see his face agen;
I am not sent for yet, I have beene ready,
Sir Clement, these three houres, and I do wonder
His Grace forgets himselfe so much.

sp.speaker: Sir Clement
sp.l: That Musick speaks him on entrance.

div.stage: Re-enter Cousen and three Servants, disguised as King and Lords.

sp.speaker: Cousen
sp.l: I, that garbe becomes him;
How was his person lost within that shapeThe “shape” refers to the dress; this is a green-room term.
He was first presented to me?

sp.speaker: Hornet
sp.l: Indeed the case is somewhat a
Altered, by your highnesse bounty
To your poore subject, Hornet.

sp.speaker: Playfaire
sp.l: Now he lookes
As he did scorne the quorum, and were hungry
To eat a Statesman; 'Las an office in
The houshold is too little for a breakfast:
A Baron, but a mornings draught, he'll gulpe it,
Like a round Egge in Muscadine: Me thinkes
At every wiping of his mouth, should drop
A golden saying of Pythagoras;
A piece of Machiavelli; I see already
Hang on his Beard (which wants but stroaking out)
The Statutes and the Magna Charta have
Taken a lease at his tongues end.

sp.speaker: Cousen
sp.l: I will think on't;
He shall be — but toth' banquet,
Then let the masque be ready, there we shall
Employ your worthy diligence.

sp.speaker: Hornet
sp.l: Heaven blesse your mightie Grace.

sp.speaker: Cousen
sp.l: You'll follow.

div.stage: Exeunt everyone but Hornet.Only the 1833 edition clarifies that everyone except Hornet exits, which allows his subsequent speech to act as a soliloquy.

sp.speaker: Hornet
sp.l: I attend you presently:
I know not what to think of these things yet,
'Tis verie strange I should be thus exalted
Without desert; best knowne unto my self.
Princes I see are mortall, and may be
Deceiv'd in placing of their honours, I
Am little better than a favorite,
If this be true: If? 'tis a question,
Let me consider wisely, it may be
I am not I. No, no, I am a Knight:
Are these my clothes? I did not use to weare such
A pocket in my sleeve and velvet hose,
Six times translated since they were a Mid-wives
Fore-part, were things I wore on holidayes.
The price of these would break a Cammels back,
And yet some men walk under 'em like Elephants,
And have varietie, as the Devill were
Their Taylour, who best knowes where all their land lies.
Then why this cost on me? it is a dreame,
And I am verie glad on't, 'tis impossible
I should be true, it does not hang together,
I will have patience till i wake agen,
And care not what becomes on't.

sp.speaker: Sir Clement
sp.l: 'Tis his Highnesse
Pleasure now the banquet's done.

sp.speaker: Hornet
sp.l: How, the banquet done? I was comming to't,
You could hardly say grace by this time.

sp.speaker: Sir Clement
sp.l: That's a ceremony growne out of use;
It was a running banquet.

sp.speaker: Hornet
sp.l: A running? so it seemes, it made great haste:
I doe dreame certainly, there's no sense nor reason
In any thing they say.

sp.speaker: Sir Clement
sp.l: You know your place,
The masque will straight begin, and his Grace wo'not
Have any one admitted, he resolves,
If the conceit affect him, it shall be
Perform'd i'th' Court hereafter, i'th' meane time
He does command all privacie: There are
Some set to guard the door; but your care must
Provide his Highnesse be not interrupted.
Back, they are rude already.

div.stage: Sir. Clement Exits — Knocking from within.

sp.speaker: Hornet
sp.l: Let me alone:
What turbulent Knave is that?

sp.speaker: Within
sp.l: I am a Countrey Gentlemen, Sir Giles;
And if I may presume upon good cloathes,
You may before his Grace call me your Cousen,
And not be asham'd; here is a Lady too.

sp.speaker: Hornet
sp.l: A Lady too? Is she with child?Sir Giles is acting as a court-wit here; he is being facetious on the similarity of sound between too and two. (v. 1833). What makes she
Here, and she be with child already?
'Tell thee none such shall be admitted, while
I am in place: More rapping? Keep the doores,
If I do fall a swearing once, look to't.

sp.speaker: Within
sp.l: I beseech you, for my wives sake.

sp.speaker: Hornet
sp.l: Thy wives?
What's he that pleads In forma pauperisforma pauperisAs a poor person : relieved of the fees and costs of a legal action because of inability to pay. (Merriam Webster adj./adv.).?

sp.speaker: Within
sp.l: A Citizen, and like you.

sp.speaker: Hornet
sp.l: Like me? thou liest: I am more like a Lord.
Thou shalt fare ne're the better for that word:
Knock downe the women, and there be a hundred.
And make their husbands drunk; the Guard are lazie:
These womens insolence will force a Statute,
I will petition to the King my self,
They may have libertie but once a yeere

To see the Gally foist According to the OED, “galley-foist” is “a state barge, esp. that of the Lord Mayor of London” (OED n. 1). Hornet is probably doing a reference to the Lord Mayor’s Show, in which the lord mayor leads a procession to Westminster, originally on a barge. The fact that the vast majority of the quotations in the OED date from the 17th century leads us to assume that this celebration was very popular in this time period., then be confined
To their Chamber, and one Prentice—yet agen.

sp.speaker: Within
sp.l: Sir Giles, Sir. Giles, you know me well enough.

sp.speaker: Hornet
sp.l: But while I am in office I'll know no body.

sp.speaker: Scrivenor
sp.l: I am your Scrivenor.

sp.speaker: Hornet
sp.l: Draw thy purse, wherein
Thou keep'st thy eares, and leave 'em at the doore;
The Guard trust none without a pawne; they'll serve,
If they be ne're redeem'd, to seethe in milke
For a sore throat: Jewes eares I know they are.

sp.speaker: Scrivenor
sp.l: Sir Giles, here's your Neece.

sp.speaker: Hornet
sp.l: My Neece? the devill she is.

sp.speaker: Neece
sp.l: Pray Uncle let me in.

sp.speaker: Hornet
sp.l: Her very voice: Ha? open the doores there;
Where is she?

sp.speaker: Within
sp.l: Whom?

sp.speaker: Hornet
sp.l: My Neece that call'd to me.

sp.speaker: Within
sp.l: None call'd: nor was there any woman here.

sp.speaker: Hornet
sp.l: No, nor my Scrivener bawling out, Sir Giles,
Not at any hand your worship.

sp.speaker: Hornet
sp.l: Then I dreame,
And I am a fool to make a question on't.

sp.speaker: Within
sp.l: Ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Hornet
sp.l: The knaves laugh at me, but let 'em, I
Shall be as merry with this tale to morrow:
What fancies men have in their sleep sometimes?
His Highnesse.
sp.stage: Re-enter Sir. Clement, Cousen and Servants, disguised as before; Cousen takes his seat.
sp.l: Where be the Ladies?

sp.speaker: Sir Clement
sp.l: They are all i'th' Masque.

sp.speaker: Hornet
sp.l: Nay, 'tis no matter, why do I aske the question?

sp.speaker: Sir Clement
sp.l: You'll see 'em, Sir, anon.

sp.speaker: Lord 1
sp.l: Wilt please your Grace?
sp.stage: Gives papers to the King (Cousen) and Hornet.
sp.l: And you Sir Giles, the subject of the Masque.

sp.speaker: Hornet
sp.l: What's here, the three Goddesses

Contention for the golden ball?They are going to represent the myth of the Judgement of Paris, one of the most famous in classical mythology. The trial takes place during the wedding of Thetis and Peleus, which was attended by all the deities except Eris, the personification of discord, who had not been invited. In revenge, this goddess threw a golden apple with the inscription “to the fairest one”, which led to the subsequent quarrel of three goddesses at the Judgement of Paris and ultimately caused the Trojan War. Here, Hornet refers to that golden apple and to the three goddesses: Juno (Hera), Pallas (Athena) and Venus (Aphrodite). In 1646 Shirley would write a whole masque inspired by this myth: The Triumph of Beauty.
sp.stage: Enter Playfaire as Paris, dancing, with a Golden Ball in his hand.
sp.l: This is ParisJupiter (Zeus), who was related to the three candidate goddesses, instructs Hermes to choose another person to act as judge in the contest. The chosen one is Paris, second son of Priam, King of Troy. Paris was abandoned at birth by his parents because Hecuba had a dream during her pregnancy: she dreamt that she would give birth to a flaming torch that would destroy the city, so Priam ordered his servant Agelaus to abandon the child on Mount Ida. Agelaus, at the last moment, took pity on the newborn and decided to raise him as his own son.; So.
These are the three Goddesses;

Juno, Pallas, Venus.The three goddesses who are candidates for the most beautiful are: Juno, sister and wife of Jupiter, goddess of love and marriage; Pallas, daughter of Jupiter, goddess of wisdom, warfare and handicraft; and Venus, aunt of Jupiter, goddess of love and beauty.

div.stage: The Goddesses dance, and court Paris for his BallIn the myth, each goddess tries to bribe Paris by offering him different gifts.: Juno enters one like a King; Takes his Crowne and Scepter, offers it to Paris, he refuses.Juno offers him power and the possibility of becoming the Emperor of Asia. Here she enters with someone disguised as a king and gives Paris the crown and sceptre he carries. Paris refuses.

sp.speaker: Lord 2
sp.l: Juno doth wooe him with her State and Kingdomes.

sp.speaker: Hornet
sp.l: But he refuses, more foole he.

div.stage: To Pallas enter one like a Soldier armed, with a book in his hand; she presents the sword and book to Paris, but he rejects them.Pallas offers him wisdom and the possibility of winning every battle. Here it is symbolised by the soldier carrying a sword and a book, but Paris also rejects her.

sp.speaker: Sir Clement
sp.l: He is not for her service, though she offer
To make him Schollar and a Souldier:
A compleat man.

sp.speaker: Hornet
sp.l: No, no, that fairie must win the ball.
sp.stage: To Venus comes Cupid, leading in Hornet's Neece, richly drest.Finally, Aphrodite offers him the love of the most beautiful woman in the world. In the myth, this woman is Helen; in the masque, it is the Neece, who enters dressed as a bride hand in hand with Cupid.
sp.l: Ha? that's my Neece.

sp.speaker: Sir Clement
sp.l: Which, Sir Giles?

sp.speaker: Hornet
sp.l: That whom Dame Venus and her DandipratdandipratAn insignificant, contemptible, or ridiculous person. Also (esp. in early use): a person of unusually small stature. Now rare and chiefly archaic (OED n. 2A).
Are busie withall.

sp.speaker: Lord 1
sp.l: Why that's the Bride.

sp.speaker: Hornet
sp.l: Bride, quothaquothaUsed with contemptuous, ironic, or sarcastic force after repeating words said by someone else: ‘he said?’, ‘she said?’; (hence) ‘indeed!’ Archaic (OED int.)?

sp.speaker: Sir Clement
sp.l: Married this morning; 'Tis my daughter, sir.

sp.speaker: Hornet
sp.l: Nay, if she be my Neece, I am sure she was not
Married this morning.
sp.stage: Paris receives the Neece, and gives Venus the Ball; Juno, Pallas, with their Masquers, Exeunt.
sp.l: She's safe enough at home,
And has but halfe her wits, as I remember:
The devill cannot juggle her from my custody.
Ha, ha, I do dreame still.

div.stage: Cupid joins their hands and sings, exits with Playfaire and Neece.Paris gives the apple to Venus and Cupid joins Playfaire’s and the Neece’s hands. By performing this masque before Hornet, they are revealing to him the marriage between Playfair and the Neece, who are also the only ones whose identity is known to us during the performance.

sp.speaker: Cousen
sp.l: 'Tis time to breake off revels: How like you this, Sir Giles?

sp.speaker: Hornet
sp.l: A very fine dreame, ifaith.

sp.speaker: Cousen
sp.l: I see you'd be a bed; You are not us'd
To these late houres.

sp.speaker: Sir Clement
sp.l: Lights for his Highnesse

sp.speaker: Hornet
sp.l: I humbly beg your license
I may returne to my owne lodging.

sp.speaker: Close
sp.l: Well, sir, 'tis easily granted.

sp.speaker: Lord 1
sp.l: Lights for Sir Giles: One shall attend you home.

sp.speaker: Hornet
sp.l: Ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Sir Clement
sp.l: Why do you laugh?

sp.speaker: Hornet
sp.l: At a conceit, at a conceit:
What did I eat last night, to make me dream thus?
